awd_titl_txt: Manufacturing the Future - Expanding Student Interest in Manufacturing Technology Careers
awd_abstract_narration:
Columbia Basin College will develop a manufacturing technology program that bridges students from high school to community college technical programs. Demand for skilled manufacturing technicians is outpacing the supply and it is projected that up to two million manufacturing jobs will go unfilled in the coming decade. The bridge program will feature a summer Manufacturing Technology Academy program for high school students and a Manufacturing Technology Professional Development Workshop for secondary school teachers and high school advisors. A Tool Kit for teaching hands-on manufacturing technology lessons in the high school classroom will be developed. Access to hands-on learning and skill development opportunities will boost student interest in pursuing manufacturing careers by combatting negative stereotypes surrounding the industry's image, as well as leading to increased self-efficacy in STEM subjects, particularly for female and underrepresented students. 

Columbia Basin College will actively partner with the Tri Tech Skills Center, a local high school that specializes in career technical education. These institutions will jointly pilot an Introduction to Manufacturing course with high school students. During the Summer Academy, students will undertake multiple experiential learning opportunities, including the design and manufacturing of a take-home product, career exploration presentations, field trips, and internships with industry partners. The opportunity to earn both high school and college credit upon successful completion of the academy will incentivize students and provide a cost-effective means for students to transition into the Manufacturing Technology program at the community college. This opportunity will stimulate the diverse high school population in the Columbia Basin College service area to pursue post-secondary Manufacturing Technology education and subsequently pursue technical careers in manufacturing technology. What is learned will inform effective practices in both bridging students into post-secondary education and effective practices engaging rural students in higher education. This project is funded by the Advanced Technological Education program that focuses on the education of technicians for the advanced-technology fields that drive the nation's economy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Columbia Basin College (CBC) was awarded a grant of $289,982.00 from the National Science Foundation’s Advanced Technological Education (ATE) program in June 2019 to develop and implement Manufacturing the Future: Expanding Student Interest in Manufacturing Technology Careers. The goal of the project was to increase the number of skilled technicians available to fill high-demand manufacturing jobs.

This project funded a Manufacturing Technology (MT) Academy that bridged students from high school to community college technical programs. The MT Academy was offered in the summers of 2021 and 2022.  Students received first-hand experience using essential hand tools and more advanced tools like welding machines, lathes, and mills. They also created and modified blueprints using AutoCAD and Solidworks software. As more advanced students progress through the program, they have the opportunity to experience using a laser cutter, CNC machine, and 3D printer. Students who successfully completed the program obtained high school and college credit.

One of the biggest highlights of the MT Academy was when one of the 2021 MT Academy participants announced that he wanted to register for the Manufacturing Technology program as a Running Start student, a dual enrollment program, in the fall of 2021. He enrolled in the program and completed the first-year curriculum.  He later served as a mentor leading activities in the 2022 MT Academy; he was able to apply his knowledge by leading SolidWorks and CNC sessions for the MT attendees.  In the 2022-2023 academic year, he passed the Certificate for SolidWorks Associate Exam and graduated with an Associate of Applied Science (AAS).  He was offered employment in the manufacturing industry one quarter before completing his degree.  In addition, a second MT Academy attendee enrolled in the Manufacturing Technology program as a Running Start student.

One of the key outcomes of our project was the substantial improvement in the curriculum for manufacturing programs in both welding and machining. This was achieved through an in-depth program review that identified outdated content. As a result, the faculty made important curricular changes, including the development of stackable credentials and the creation of a new welding pathway focused on structural and fabrication skills. This enhanced curriculum ensures that students receive training that aligns with industry standards and prepares them for the workforce.  For machining, this alignment included preparing students for the Certified SOLIDWORKS Associate (CSWA) exam. This globally recognized credential validates their proficiency in 3D CAD modeling and design concepts, enhancing their employability in design and engineering fields. In addition, the CTE division made significant strides in closing the equity gap by securing funding for scholarships and resources for manufacturing students.

This grant also helped evaluate other programs at the college and helped identify their direct or indirect alignment with manufacturing. CBC is in the process of implementing the programming of 3D printers in the computer science and cyber security departments. The college has already implemented 3D printing in the engineering department.  CBC will be offering an AAS in Supply Chain and Logistics beginning the 2023-2024 academic year that has direct ties to the manufacturing program. CBC is also exploring grant funding to start up a mechatronics program in the near future. Other programs also impacted by further evaluation of manufacturing alignment include Nuclear Technology, Occupational Safety and Health, and Cyber Security. 

In summary, this project helped invest in the professional development of educators by providing them the skills and knowledge necessary to deliver high-quality programs, identify equipment upgrade needs, identify and implement industry-relevant curricula, industry engagement, and provide real-world experiences to our students.  These enhancements shape a brighter future for students enrolled in the programs and help prepare a more robust workforce increasing the employability of our graduates.

 

 


Last Modified: 09/28/2023
Modified by: Jesus Mota
